keyTakeAways: Miami Beach is developing a 7-mile-long artificial reef called Reefline, combining marine art and ecological restoration.
The project includes 22 concrete cars arranged in an underwater traffic jam, designed to serve as coral substrates.
The reef will be located about 700 feet off Miami Beach, in water about 15–20 feet deep, making it accessible to swimmers without boats.
Coral species such as gorgonians are being cultivated in nurseries and transplanted onto the reef to restore native Caribbean reef habitats.
The project is funded by a $5 million city bond approved by voters, with an additional $6 million sought through public fundraising.
Artists like Leandro Ehrlich and curator Ximena Caminos are integral to the design and vision, blending art and science.
Reefline aims to restore a coral reef that once existed in Miami Beach but was lost due to sand replenishment in the 1970s.
The project includes educational components, such as a marine learning center, and may one day feature a constellation of 57 giant starfish as a symbolic landmark.
The project is both an ecotourism initiative and a cultural placemaking effort, with the goal of creating underwater homes for fish and enhancing community connection to marine ecosystems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a 7-mile-long artificial reef combining marine art and coral restoration. The project, led by artist Ximena Caminos and coral expert Colin Foord, will feature 22 concrete cars and other sculptures arranged in the ocean off Miami Beach, designed to support the growth of resilient corals like gorgonians. These corals will eventually transform the sculptures into vibrant underwater ecosystems, restoring a reef that was lost in the 1970s. The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and seeks $6 million more in public funding. It will be accessible to swimmers in 15–20 feet of water and includes a marine learning center to educate the public. Over time, the coral will colonize the structures, with future phases including 57 giant starfish sculptures that may become a symbolic landmark for Miami Beach. The initiative blends art, science, and environmental restoration, aiming to revive both marine biodiversity and cultural identity in the city.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
